docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER Massachusetts became the first state to enact near-universal health care coverage this month, Robert E. Travaglini, the State Senate president, allowed himself a bit of bravado. ''This is going to be a template for the rest of the nation to follow, and not just this,'' Mr. Travaglini crowed, rattling off a list of recent Massachusetts milestones. ''We did this for same-sex marriage; we did this for stem cell research. Massachusetts is at the head of the curve.''
docs.abstract: Pam Belluck article notes that states like Massachusetts and South Dakota are proceeding on their own on issues like health care, abortion and gay marriage, and discusses whether America is destined to balkanize into patchwork of polar-opposite policies; map; photos (M)
docs.snippet: With the political and ideological extremes bubbling up from the states, is the country destined to balkanize into a patchwork of polar-opposite policies?

docs.lead_paragraph: ON May 9, Newark will elect a new mayor. For the first time in two decades, it will not be Sharpe James. The new mayor will face numerous challenges as he tries to ensure that Newark's downtown ''renaissance'' expands to other neighborhoods, many still troubled by poverty and crime. Few of these challenges will be more important than improving the Newark public schools, under state control since 1995. In the next year, the district -- the state's largest, with nearly 43,000 students -- will be eligible to return to local control under the state's new accountability law. Even if that happens, the new mayor will still lack direct authority over a district operated by the State Department of Education. But he can nonetheless make an enormous contribution to Newark's schools.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by City University of New York Prof Jean Anyon and Rutgers-Newark Prof Alan Sadovnik outline number of things new mayor can do to help ensure success of public schools in Newark, NJ, even while they are under control of state (M)
docs.snippet: The new mayor of Newark needs to think community, not just classrooms.

byline.original: By Jean Anyon and Alan Sadovnik

docs.lead_paragraph: Their first major initiative since quitting the A.F.L.-C.I.O will focus on workers whose jobs cannot be shipped overseas.

headline.main: New Labor Group Beginning Drive for Higher Pay
headline.print_headline: New Labor Group Beginning Drive for Higher Pay

docs.snippet: Their first major initiative since quitting the A.F.L.-C.I.O will focus on workers whose jobs cannot be shipped overseas.

docs.lead_paragraph: The health insurer Aetna said yesterday that it would not pay for a nerve-stimulating implant the government has approved as a last-ditch treatment for severe depression. While some analysts said the national noncoverage decision is a continuation of existing policy that came as no surprise, investors saw it as a blow for the device's manufacturer, Cyberonics. The company, based in Houston, has been citing previous case-by-case approvals of coverage by 8 of Aetna's more than 50 local and regional health plans as a sign of growing acceptance of the device among insurers.

headline.main: Aetna Will Not Cover Implant to Treat Severe Depression

docs.abstract: Health insurer Aetna says it will not pay for nerve-stimulating implant made by Cyberonics that Food and Drug Administration has approved as last-ditch treatment for severe depression (M)
docs.snippet: While some analysts said the decision is a continuation of existing policy that came as no surprise, investors saw it as a blow for the device's manufacturer, Cyberonics.

docs.lead_paragraph: A chart in Business Day on Wednesday with an article about the auto industry's efforts to rein in health care costs misstated the severance alternatives for some workers at General Motors. (The error also appeared in a chart on March 23.) Hourly workers nearing retirement who leave immediately will receive up to $2,900 a month until they reach their 30th anniversary of service. They must retire at that point and will receive a full pension. They cannot work in the interim, and the money is not in addition to their regular pay.
docs.abstract: April 19 chart with article about auto industry's efforts to rein in health care costs misstated severance alternatives for some workers at General Motors

docs.lead_paragraph: James F. Berg, the chief negotiator for the city's building owners, said he was still convinced, some eight hours before a strike deadline, that the union representing 28,000 apartment-building workers would stage a walkout. But in the end, about an hour after the initial deadline of 12:01 a.m. yesterday, management and the union reached a deal, with both sides making concessions that they had said they would never make and both sides still able to claim victory.

headline.main: Labor Deal With Doormen Is Chalked Up to Compromise on Both Sides

docs.abstract: New York City doormen's union and city building owners agree to four-year deal and avoid imminent walkout by some 28,000 apartment-building workers; deal is described by both sides as model of compromise; workers are asked to accept raise lower than inflation rate, but will receive additional financial support for medical plan and benefits; one-year wage freeze demanded by building owners is reduced to six-month delay in raises; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Management and the union reached a deal, with both sides making concessions that they had said they would never make and both sides still able to claim victory.

byline.original: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE; Colin Moynihan contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Robert B. Wegman, a pioneer of one-stop shopping who transformed his family's business, Wegmans Food Markets Inc., into one of the largest private companies in the country, died here on Thursday. He was 87. His death was announced in a company statement; the cause was not disclosed.

headline.main: Robert Wegman, 87, Leader In Supermarket Innovations

docs.abstract: Robert Wegman, pioneer of one-stop shopping who transformed Wegmans Food Markets into one of country's largest private companies, dies at age 87; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Robert B. Wegman, a pioneer of one-stop shopping, transformed his family's business, Wegmans Food Markets Inc., into one of the largest private companies in the country.

docs.lead_paragraph: The financial challenge of retirement is to make one's money last while paying health care costs that inevitably increase with age. It is becoming clear that to meet that challenge, many older Americans will need to cash in their home equity. In a report last year, the National Council on Aging, a research and advocacy organization, made a compelling case for expanding the use of specialized loans known as reverse mortgages to help older people pay for the care they need to remain safely at home, even as they become frailer. The idea is to free up money to improve the quality of daily life, while delaying or averting the need for a nursing home. And since that should also be the nation's overall goal when it comes to the well-being of the elderly, reverse mortgages have to be regarded as a kind of social policy.
docs.abstract: Editorial holds that report in 2005 by National Council on Aging made compelling case for expanding use of specialized loans known as reverse mortgages to help older people pay for care they need to remain safely at home; contends that states and federal government need to enact comprehensive incentives and consumer protections to encourage people to use reverse mortgages; says reverse mortgages are bound to become social norm as broad middle class of aging Americans begins to face financial squeeze
docs.snippet: Specialized loans known as reverse mortgages can help older people pay for the care they need to remain safely at home, even as they become frailer.
